Title: Object: View of Alexandria in Egypt, while possessed by the French in 1801
Description: Outline views in three horizontal sections; upper, Lake Maraeotis in the distance, the French camp on the cliff-top to the right, Pompey's pillar a little further inland on the horizon and mash and salt in the foreground; middle, hills, on which are seen, from left to right, Old Alexandria, Fort Cafferelli, Cleopatra's needle, Fort Cretin, Alexandria, the custom house and Little Pharos, at the edge of the bay to the far right, the mast-heads of the 'Egyptienne' and other ships in harbour, seen above the hills, with plains in front where battles were fought on 13th and 21st March 1801, French Grand Guard of cavalry to the left, British Piquet cavalry and quarters of the 3rd Guards to the right; lower, view across the plains towards the sea, where the British fleet are blockading the city, with Pharos on the far left, a mosque on the dunes in the middle distance, a statue found in the entrenchments and placed by Colonel Turner in the lines, the lines and parade of the British 3rd Guard, redout of the Reserve, attacked by the French on the 21st and the ruins of a Roman station on the far right; with crosses and circle marked in the side margins of each level. 1802 Etching
Associated events: Associated Event: Battle of Alexandria March 1801
Acquisition notes: The 'Book of Donations 1756-1823' records a large number of prints given by William Alexander, who had been appointed Keeper of Prints & Drawings in 1808, to the BM on 8 December 1810. One of them was a view of Alexandria after General Turner.
